reasoning:
First things first, Microsoft lies well outside my circle of competence. I don’t pretend to understand every twist and turn of software platforms, cloud architecture, and enterprise licensing as deeply as I do consumer staples, railroads or simple utilities. Risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing, and I’d be taking on unnecessary risk by diving into a highly technical business.  

As for the moat, sure, Microsoft has sturdy operating margins around 89% and a stable franchise in Windows, Office and Azure. But their ROE has been a modest 7.7% on average, with only 0 out of 10 periods exceeding 15%. That inconsistency tells me their competitive advantage can be eroded by disruptive change—far different than the wide moats of Coca-Cola or See’s Candies where pricing power and brand loyalty endure.  

Management has done a creditable job growing book value per share, but recent stock issuances raise questions about shareholder-friendly capital allocation. Dividends are still a drop in the bucket relative to their cash flows. I like managers who think and act like owners, and issuing new shares isn’t my first choice of how to reward shareholders.  

On the balance sheet, Microsoft is conservative—debt-to-equity sits below 0.5 and free cash flows are plentiful. Yet their return on invested capital is a mere 5.2%, and their earnings growth over the last ten years, while 72.7% in total, has been uneven from period to period. I prefer companies that compound earnings predictably year after year.  

Most importantly, the valuation is simply too rich. Your three-stage DCF pegs intrinsic value at roughly $53,000, and even after a 15% haircut you still get $45,377. At today’s price the margin of safety is negative 82.6%. As I often say, “It’s far better to buy a wonderful company at a fair price than a fair company at a wonderful price.” Microsoft looks like the latter—no margin of safety to be found.  

Long term, I admire the franchise and the depth of the management bench. But in 20 years I’d rather own businesses I clearly understand and that I can purchase at sensible levels—think Coca-Cola, Apple (as a consumer play), or my insurance operations. Microsoft simply doesn’t stack up against the opportunities in my portfolio when I apply my stringent criteria.  

So I’ll pass—there’s no penalty for missing a good opportunity, only for buying at too steep a price.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 7.7%; Conservative debt levels; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 72.7% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 86.7%) suggest some competitive advantage; High performance stability (75.1%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (5.8%, 5y), Stage 2 (2.9%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
